turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Oh, don't be so coy, dear. You're going to Rio.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: That's right. You're going to Rio. Rio de Janeiro. On your own. Come on, you should know. You bought the fucking ticket.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: But I bet you didn't say you were going to split on him.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Don't lie to me. Don't treat me like that.

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: What do we do here, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Well, it's a wide range of, eh --

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: -- is often sneered at. Are you aware of that?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Not any real sneering as such, no.

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: There's a whole wide world out there, and it all needs to be accounted for, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: Oh, it's unfashionable, I know, but, yes, we're methodical, yes, we're dilligent, yes, we're serious, and where's the crime in that, and why not shout it from the rooftops, yes, maybe sometimes we are a little bit boring, but by God, we get the job done.

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: And that's why I think you fit in here.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Oh, I see, I thought you meant --

turns.speaker: LUMSDEN
turns.text: Which is why I'm trusting you with this account.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That guy, the one that died.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, here, I mean, where else?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Would you like to come in?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Would you like to see the rest?

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: Well, I've been away for a bit, travelling, that sort of thing, and now I'm trying to write a novel.

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: Yeah. Well, maybe I'll change it.

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: Yes, I mean, who wants to read about another dead priest? It's about some other guy, some guy who's not a priest, who doesn't die. You see, it's better already.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Do you think you could answer that?

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: The telephone? It continues to ring.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Yes, the telephone, but if it's for me, I'm not in. HUGO You're not in.

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: It was some guy called Brian.

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: A little bit. Is that good or bad?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: No, just leave it. He knows I must be at home. I'm working nights this week.

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: And he's a patient of yours?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: And that's not the same thing?

turns.speaker: HUGO
turns.text: No, but like all novelists, I'm in search of the self.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: October 15th, direct flight, London Heathrow to Rio de Janeiro, British Airways, you are looking at seven hundred and sixty-five pounds. Seven six five.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Air Portugal, on the other hand, via Lisbon, same day, five hundred and sixty-five. Five six five. It's up to you. Catering important?

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Air France. Glasgow. Direct, but then you're looking at the wrong end of nine hundred and twelve pounds. That's nine one two. It's up to you.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Yes, the first one's fine. Heathrow direct.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: It's up to you. Air Patagonia. New outfit: via Caracas and Bogot . No catering. Four hundred and eleven pounds. Four one one. Good value, but refueling at Bogot  is variable.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Well, it's up to you. Seven six five. How will you be paying?

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: Take all the time you like, doctor.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm sorry, I've never seen any of them.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: Do you think you have a good memory for faces?

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: But in your work you must meet lots of different people, every day -- new people, new faces. No?

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: And what do you recognize, names or faces?

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: Like recognizing criminals by their crimes.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: I mean, that's what it's like.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: And you said you supposed so, but I wasn't offering it for debate.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: Excellent. DC Mitchell is a rising star, Mr. Stevens. Under my tutelage he will undoubtedly make the grade.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: It's like recognizing criminals by their crimes.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You can tell by the intonation.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: One other thing. Do you have any tattoos?

turns.speaker: ANJANETTE
turns.text: You're in a good mood today, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, baby. Things are great. Listen, there's Devra, whatta you want?

turns.speaker: ANJANETTE
turns.text: Don't you think there's too much gold?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's great.  You wanna speak to Mary? Hold on...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, would you argue with your doctor?

turns.speaker: ANJANETTE
turns.text: I thought you were in a good mood.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I am... except I've gotta do somebody at their house.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, it's a very groovy girl.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: She's a very groovy girl. That's the problem.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, it's a small town. Sooner or later things catch up with you... don't they?

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Do you think George is a fairy?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Well, I don't know for sure... he's a hairdresser.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Maybe he's just a kooky guy who likes doing something kooky like that.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: I'm thinking of investing with him. He worries me.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Maybe he's too flighty and irresponsible. That's why I asked if he was a fairy.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I don't know. He's a hairdresser.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: You suggested it, don't you think it's a good idea?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: That you were just indulging me.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: No, doll, I listen to you. And if a deal loses money that's not so bad either if it's handled right.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: It's just -- fabulous.  Think you could do anything for me?

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: -- yes, Senator -- just a minute, dear --

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Lester, don't you think that uhh --

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: That girl's making an awful spectacle of herself.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: What do you expect me to do about it?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I just thought you'd like to know --

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Why would I like to know if there's nothing I can do about it, goddammit --

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- I hope you like Miss Shawn --

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: -- what, who? Oh she's very nice, yes -- I mean normally ---

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- cause she's going to be very, very expensive.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Can't we go into this later, sweetheart?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: We cannot go into this later.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: You make me sick. Just be straight for once in your life.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: -- yes, we're all trying to do something to make this a better country to live in, believe it or not.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- is that what this is all about?

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Yes and you don't have to be sarcastic about it, that's a beautiful thing he's doing -- some people do more than go to the beauty parlor and shop at Saks --

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Lester, you're a miserable man. You're not helping anybody. You're just twisting arms to raise money for a lot of silly son of a bitches that are out for themselves -- this is just business, don't kid yourself. And you know the worst thing about it, even if it does somebody some good somewhere which I can't possibly imagine, you'll never know the difference. You're just sweating and kidding yourself - and you're kidding yourself if you think your new business partner is going to keep his hands off that girl -- or that she'll keep her hands off him.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- think what you have time to think, Lester.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Whoever she is, she doesn't give up, does she?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I thought you said you weren't going anywhere.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm not. I mean I've gotta see this friend of mine for a few minutes.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: You mean that girl, don't you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll be right back, it's just that this girl is a different girl... she has attacks.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: These attacks... it's got something to do with her... uh... pancreas.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Does she have a pancreatic ulcer?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: That's very serious. Who's her doctor?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Ruth Lesserman had a pancreatic ulcer.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: It turned out to be cancer.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: So what are you doing going over there? You're not her doctor.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I've gotta give her some pills. Percodan, she ran out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And listen, I'll be right back and I want your ass in that bed when I get back.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: You're very rude... if you don't come back --

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll be back in a while.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I don't want to see you anymore.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll be right back, baby, really.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But you don't know what happened.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I don't care about that girl, I don't care if she's dead.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I'm perfectly calm, George, I'm simply saying you have no respect for me, that you're incapable of distinguishing between me and one of your average Hollywood... mummers...

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- Numbers, and I don't need to place myself in that kind of position.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- I like myself far too much, far too much.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't want to place you in any position --

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: -- to be put in that kind of position...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll have Mary wash you. Mary!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm coming, baby --  How's Otis doing, anyway?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I'm not used to that kind of treatment.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I've never been treated that way, and I'm not going to start now.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Jesus, I don't know, baby, I been cutting too much hair lately. I'm losing all my concepts...

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: We have this political thing tonight. Could you comb me out at the house?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know. I'm beginning to feel guilty.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All I ever do is play. I should be doing something to get my own shop open.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: The shop. I think you're a good investment, and I don't mind telling him.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, listen, baby, I'm a star.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know. Just a minute...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: She's fine. You really think I'd be a good investment?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I wouldn't say so if I didn't.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: And I certainly wouldn't tell Lester.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: I mean it or I wouldn't say it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's great. You look great, baby, great. Dennis, look at Felicia's hair.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Comb my hair out later, honey.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, that's okay, I'll do It now.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: No, baby... I'm glad you're coming tonight.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Right now, I just don't care.

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Why didn't you come alone? Lester invited you. Did you have to bring her?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Sweetheart, it's a bore out there... let's lock the door.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Holy Christ. You want to get us killed?

turns.speaker: FELICIA
turns.text: Don't be silly. I'll just tell Lester we were smoking a couple of joints. See?

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: You're rude. I mean, you're very rude.

turns.speaker: GEORGE'S VOICE
turns.text: Hey, I tried to get her off the phone.

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: GEORGE'S VOICE
turns.text: No, baby. Now look, that girl that called -- I have to talk to her, she'll do something.

turns.speaker: GEORGE'S VOICE
turns.text: I don't know, kill herself. She's O.D.'d four times.

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: Are you in love with her?

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: No. You know too many sick ladies.

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: How do you expect to get anything done if you allow yourself to get sidetracked? Particularly in your business... you deal with women every day...

turns.speaker: FELICIA'S VOICE
turns.text: Don't worry, honey, I'll protect you.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: You here to see my mother?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: She's out, but you're supposed to wait.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: This is the one thing I like about this house... want some lox?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: Are you gay?... baked apple?... they're cold but they're good.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: Well, are you? Are you queer?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: C'mon, are you or aren't you?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: C'mon, tell me. Don't be afraid.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why do you wanna know so bad?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: See if you've been making it with my mother.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What would my being a faggot have to do with that?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: Nothing, I guess... have you ever made it with a guy?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Have you ever made it with a girl?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah... I've made it with a girl...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'd like to do your hair sometime.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: ... just, you could look very heavy...

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: You don't have to make conversation with me, I'm not my mother... do you have a thing about older women... that's sort of faggoty isn't it?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: I never get my hair done.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: In fact, I don't think I've ever been to a beauty parlor in my whole life.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: You think that's funny, don't you?

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: You live a phony cheap cop-out existence.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: Beverly Hills hairdresser... what kind of a thing is that to do... you might as well be a faggot... think that's funny too?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That you're just like your mother.

turns.speaker: LORNA
turns.text: I am not like my mother!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look...  Do you wanna fuck me?

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: Oh yes. Mrs. Shumann called about you.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: I went to school with her husband.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: So you want to go in business for yourself?

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: You do know what money's like these days.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: Jesus, look at this. Nine, nine and three quarters -- that's our prime rate. And I'll tell you something else: the big boys are going for it.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: After all, Mr. Roundy, we're paying six percent. Six percent. FHA's at eight and a half -- no, we won't be going back to the old days.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: It's got nothing to do with inflation. Rates, for example, rise independently of tight money if you look at interest curves carefully. Historically, that's always been true, though most people don't realize it.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: What sort of references do you have?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Her hair, I do Barbara Rush.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: I mean credit references, Mr. Roundy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I've got the customers... that's my point. I'm the one they want. If I had my own shop, they'd leave and come to me. I have a lot of customers.

turns.speaker: PETTIS
turns.text: Look, Mr. Roundy, why don't you make out a financial statement? It'll save us both some time. Miss Michaels here can show you... have it notarized and we'll see where we go from there. Miss Michaels, would you get me a couple of forms?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You're late, we're all backed up and you're supposed to go to Buffums.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You promised you'd do the show.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Don't use that tone of voice with me... never mind, I'll take Gordon.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Devra, try Jackie Shawn will you? And if you don't reach her, keep trying.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Somebody's going to have to wash Mrs. Young. Mary's not here.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, Norman, I'm not the shampoo girl.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Great. Who's been doing your hair?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: -- Listen, I'm supposed to take Jill to El Cholo tonight. She's really going to be pissed if I don't.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: -- Maybe she'll come with us. If I tell her how important it is to me, I don't think she'll mind. Do you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Great... so how's everything with you?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Oh, about six weeks now... Lester -- well, he's very sweet.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: He's a very private person, actually.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah -- he doesn't happen to know that we went together, does he?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: -- Well no. It never came up.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: -- What for? Honey, I'll see you later.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Shut up, it's all right.  Do you want a drink?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Where do you want to do this?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Can't you do it out here?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Okay... but I want you to know one thing.  I've got to look great tonight, I mean I have to look great, okay?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: She's incredible...  She loves you, George.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: ... I don't get it done often.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: It's the sauna, I keep the sauna on and it makes the whole bathroom hot.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Not too much, don't cut too much.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Jackie, would you argue with your doctor.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Bernstein... seemed to think I hated men.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Do you? You still see him?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: ... he tried to... uh... make it with me.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: It was after you, baby. After you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Boy, that sauna is really... can't you turn it down or something?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: No... Lester likes it on all the time in case he wants to use it.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Anyway, he offered me a silver cloud. At least he should give me a Ferrari and pay off my house and give me a nine carat ring or something...

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: There was nothing to know. Anyway... if I can't have love I have to at least have money. I have to have some pride I can do something.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I just have to do one little thing.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: If you screw me up for tonight, I'll kill you, I swear to God, I'll kill you.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Can I count on that? I just want to see Lester with me and that cunt in the same room tonight.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Well, did you or didn't you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now, baby... if I told you about her... then you couldn't count on me not telling anymore... could you?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You did, I know you did.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: One of my few virtues is discretion.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You just can't stand to miss one of them, can you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't want to... I swear...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know... you don't know, I know.
